executive_summary: The Gasoline and Petroleum Wholesaling industry has contended with highly volatile conditions through the current period, enduring heavily fluctuating crude oil prices. Overall, wholesalers have benefited from the soaring demand for oil. Revenue has climbed at an expected CAGR of 2.5% to $948.2 billion through the current period, despite a 5.5% decline in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Disrupts Oil Consumption Trends
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic led to plummeting demand for travel, limiting demand for gasoline, jet fuel and engine lubricants. Even so, stay-at-home orders forced consumers to cook at home more frequently, supporting demand for petroleum tanks for barbecues and gas for gas stoves.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Oil Prices Disrupt Wholesalers' Performance
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Petroleum wholesalers' performance follows world crude oil prices. Through the current period, oil prices have heavily fluctuated because of the COVID-19 pandemic and the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, leading to extreme revenue volatility.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Wholesalers Get Smaller as Integrated Companies Seek Higher Profit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Some major oil companies have shifted away from wholesaling operations in favor of refining. The remaining petroleum wholesalers are overwhelmingly small private companies that rely more on labor. Intense competition has encouraged gas and petroleum wholesalers to consolidate.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Environmental Awareness Reduces Consumers' Reliance on Petroleum
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising environmental consciousness among consumers has encouraged the adoption of fossil fuel substitutes like hybrid and electric vehicles, shifting demand away from motor gasoline.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Ebbing Oil Prices Will Mitigate Wholesalers' Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Oil prices will drastically drop through the outlook period as supply normalizes and demand trends downward. Lower oil prices and reduced demand will force wholesalers to lower product prices, squeezing sales.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition Will Intensify as Substitutes Gain Traction
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The campaign against fossil fuels will continue through the outlook period, urging consumers to consider alternative energy sources like electric vehicles and renewable energy, posing a threat to the gasoline and petroleum supply chain.

Recent legislative pushes toward improved fuel efficiency for cars and light trucks will moderate growth for petroleum wholesalers through the outlook period, as automakers produce more hybrid and electric vehicles.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Companies Will Manage Low Profit Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Due to volatility in the petroleum supply chain, most wholesalers endure razor-thin profit. To mitigate costs, wholesalers will rely more on part-time labor and advanced inventory management systems.

industry_definition: The Gasoline and Petroleum Wholesaling industry distributes most of the same products as the Gasoline and Petroleum Bulk Stations industry, but on a smaller scale. Operators purchase petroleum products directly from bulk stations and sell them to retailers, manufacturers and natural gas retail distributors.
key_trends: The COVID-19 pandemic spurred oil price volatility, which trickled down to wholesalers. Sales of petroleum products plummeted amid stay-at-home orders and surged when travel restrictions eased.

Integrated oil companies are shifting away from wholesaling operations toward refining, increasing market fragmentation. New and existing petroleum wholesalers are overwhelmingly small private companies.

The shift towards renewable energy sources and the incentivization of hybrid vehicles will threaten petroleum sales in the long term. Consumers and policymakers are focusing on increasing the accessibility of renewable energy to reduce the country's reliance on fossil fuels.
Gasoline and petroleum wholesalers receive little public assistance. Most wholesalers retain membership in trade associations.

Reporting and documentation requirements help promote transparency and accountability in managing toxic chemicals. Petroleum wholesalers must report on chemical release and waste management for public awareness.

tier_1_suppliers: Refined Petroleum Pipeline Transportation in the US
Tank & Refrigeration Trucking in the US
Gasoline & Petroleum Bulk Stations in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Oil Drilling & Gas Extraction in the US
Electrical Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Metal Pipe & Tube Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Auto Parts Stores in the US
Gas Stations with Convenience Stores in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The industry's performance is heavily influenced by crude oil prices. Rising crude prices fuel revenue growth but also raise purchase costs. Receding crude prices pose a threat.
Gas stations are an important downstream market. When their sales increase, they purchase more from petroleum wholesalers. Increased travel has supported demand.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Petroleum bulk storage facilities are subject to the reporting requirements of Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act of 1986 (EPCRA) and of Section 6607 of the Pollution Prevention Act of 1990 (PPA), commonly referred to as the Toxic Release Inventory (TRI). Petroleum storage facilities have to report annually on chemical release and waste management.

Petroleum wholesalers must provide sales documentation like invoices, shipping papers or other documentation for each commercial sale of petroleum products. Documentation has to identify the quantity and name of the product, the grade of the product, the automotive fuel rating, the oxygenate type and content (if applicable), the name and address of the seller and buyer and the date and time of the sale.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Wholesaling petroleum requires significant capital investment in storage and transportation facilities, tankers and other vehicles. Acquiring sufficient funds and suitable infrastructure and equipment can impede entrants.

basis_points.basis_title: Skilled employees are a competitive advantage
basis_points.basis_description: Skilled employees are a competitive advantage for petroleum wholesalers. The pool of employees with sufficient skills to safely blend fuels is limited.

basis_points.basis_title: Internal competition is a greater burden than external competition
basis_points.basis_description: Internal competition is a greater burden on wholesalers than external competition. Petroleum wholesalers compete fiercely to retain retail and industrial customers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Integrated refiners move away from wholesaling
concentration_points.concentration_description: Although many petroleum wholesalers are integrated with other parts of the supply chain, few wholesalers also control refining businesses. Integrated petroleum refiners have been moving away from product wholesaling because of the slim profit margins.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The massive scale of the petroleum sector keeps wholesaling fragmented
concentration_points.concentration_description: Because of the substantial downstream demand for gasoline and petroleum products, there are more than 2,000 petroleum wholesalers in the US in 2023. These wholesalers serve a vast array of niche markets, furthering fragmentation.

top_companies.company_name: Harbour Petroleum Corp. of Brevard Inc.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Petroleum wholesalers purchase goods like motor gasoline, distillate fuel oil, bottled liquefied petroleum gas, kerosene and other refined and crude oils, for resale. While wholesalers' purchase costs can change dramatically from year to year, they've remained stable through the current period since companies adjusted their purchase volumes according to commodity price fluctuations.

Labor costs are relatively insignificant for petroleum wholesalers since operations are more capital-intensive than labor-intensive. Technological advancements have enabled petroleum wholesalers to retain the minimal labor needed to maintain facilities. Wage costs have been relatively steady through the current period, increasing marginally as a revenue share.

Volatile crude oil prices threaten profit margins for less established petroleum wholesalers. To neutralize price fluctuations, wholesalers establish long-term contracts with buyers and suppliers. Wholesalers commonly mark up prices; this practice cushions profit during economic downturns like the COVID-19 pandemic.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Wholesaling petroleum requires significant capital investment in storage and transportation facilities, tankers and other vehicles. Acquiring sufficient funds and suitable infrastructure and equipment can impede entrants.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.
The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Petroleum wholesalers are sensitive to shifts in oil prices
volatility_points.volatility_description: Oil prices skyrocket during shortages or periods of excess demand and fall during periods of excess supply or low demand. Global economic and political shifts can cause the world price of crude oil to surge or plummet nearly overnight.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Domestic trips surged amid widespread vaccination
volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers largely postponed or canceled travel plans during the pandemic; as governments lifted lockdown restrictions, many individuals flocked to airports or started road trips, expressing pent-up demand for travel.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in such a crowded industry?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry maintain a competitive edge by maintaining proper relationships with customers and garnering high efficiency.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any one market, major customer or other isolated revenue stream?
FAQs.answer: Operators in this industry are heavily dependent on sales of petroleum and gasoline. The majority of sales are to other gasoline wholesalers, who specialize in last-mile delivery and comprise over 70.0% of revenue.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company affect its profitability and growth potential?
FAQs.answer: While the largest operators in this industry are generally the most profitable, during down years they are also generally the ones who fare the worst.

FAQs.question: How do you manage volatile demand that results from economic conditions or seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Operators are directly effected by movement in oil prices and production. When oil prices increase operators generally garner higher revenue, when they fall the opposite occurs. The COVID-19 (coronavirus) crisis has caused great stress on operators. Both demand for industry products and the price of gasoline plummeted in response to the crisis, leading to steep declines in revenue.

FAQs.question: How are increased digitalization for businesses and the growing popularity of online shopping affecting your financial performance?
FAQs.answer: As operators sell mostly to large industrial clients on a greater scale this has not necessarily effected sales directly. That said, increasing digitization has forced operators to provide platforms for clients to purchase industry goods online.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology into the purchasing process to make buying more efficient for customers?
FAQs.answer: Efficiency in the purchasing process is of paramount importance to those operators that would like to find success in this industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all relevant health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Keeping a minimum level of health and safety is of paramount importance to operators in this industry. If health and safety standards are not met, a company could potentially face fines.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor potential changes to the regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: The regulatory environment for oil and gas has a significant effect on industry demand so operators must be weary of potential regulatory changes. The new presidential administration is expected to increase the level of regulation on the broader oil and gas industry, which will likely also impact downstream operators, such as industry operators.

FAQs.question: What immediate financial challenges are you likely to face in the next year?
FAQs.answer: Potential volatility in the price of oil is a constant challenge that operators in this industry face. Additionally, companies in the industry have become unattractive given their involvement in fossil fuels, which will inevitably impact their ability to receive both equity and debt financing.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected your purchase costs and selling prices over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Falling prices during the period provided increased profits for operators but lowered revenue.

FAQs.question: How do you pass on cost increases to your customers?
FAQs.answer: Since oil and gas costs fluctuate violently, it is imperative for distributors to be able to pass on any increases in the medium to long term to ensure profitability. That being said, overall demand for industry products can also fluctuate significantly. This dynamic has been demonstrated during the pandemic as total vehicle miles driven has plummeted, even though gas prices were low.

FAQs.question: Do you have long-term contracts with suppliers of key inputs? How do fluctuating input prices affect these contracts?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry must ensure a supply of the products traded; the establishment of contracts with bulk terminals is advantageous.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts across a range of markets? Are there any other markets you can expand into?
FAQs.answer: Since direct selling is the major method adopted within this industry, it is imperative that sales staff have good contacts across a range of markets. The largest market for industry operators is wholesale resellers, who primarily specialize in last-mile logistics for industry products.

FAQs.question: How have volatile fuel prices affected your sales? How will you take advantage of an increase in the world price of crude oil?
FAQs.answer: When crude oil prices rise, petroleum product prices also rise, fueling industry revenue growth. However, growth in crude oil prices also tends to raise industry purchase costs, negatively affecting profit margin. The COVID-19 (coronavirus) crisis has demonstrated the impacts of sharp price movements on the industry. At the beginning of the pandemic, prices plummeted, with the front-month contract even turning negative briefly. As a result of these swings, industry revenue collapsed in 2020, although it is expected to recover in 2021 and 2022.

FAQs.question: How will you plan for an increase in oil production? Do you have the capacity to handle increased energy usage?
FAQs.answer: High levels of oil production result in a greater volume of petroleum product output, which directly bolsters demand for wholesale distribution services offered by industry operators. Since the start of the pandemic, oil production has fallen, but will likely expand as the crisis comes to an end.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that your company complies with federal and local regulations? Have you had issues with compliance in the past?
FAQs.answer: The complex nature of the products in this industry, their importance to the US economy and the potential environmental and safety impacts of spillage or improper blending of chemicals all mean that this industry deals with substantial federal and state regulation. The new presidential administration is expected to increase the level of regulations on the industry.
